job_title: Visiting Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Some of the faculty and staff are lovely, tho everyone is overworked doing more than one person’s job, so it’s difficult to get to know anyone outside of school.
cons: Particularly in the College of Arts and Humanities, there isn’t much of a money flow at all, no classroom supplies and requests falling on the deaf ears of the two deans neither of whom are artists, but of the college of arts humanities, visual and performing arts makes up the majority. There is also a lot of minimizing of work load and lack of understanding that most arts be they visual or performing are relying on a class room experience of experiential learning and one on one time with the professor, stacking classes full to the brim when there aren’t enough supplies or tools is not just detrimental to learning but also in some cases dangerous when there are power tools/sharp objects involved. The health care is incredibly expensive as it’s privatized, and the salary for any position (at least within the college of arts and humanities) is the lowest end of the National average, so that with the expensive privatized healthcare and very meager moving stipend, I wouldn’t recommend a big move to this university. I would also do my due diligence and check out their rate of acceptance. I found they let just about any student of any level in which causes some head achingly frustrating reading/writing levels as well as general apathy or malaise as most students don’t care about school and are being forced to go to college by their wealthy parents. The school also preaches diversity and inclusion, yet does not put forward funding when requested for recruitment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Charles, MO
pros: They'll hire almost anyone, which is good if you're fresh out of college, but it wears out the experienced employees. It's a beautiful campus in a growing town. There are plenty of good people there; maybe not all are good employees/bosses, but almost everyone is easy to get along with. They're expanding rapidly, constantly offering new jobs at new campuses or departments.
cons: The rapid expansion doesn't seem to have an overall goal, other than increasing enrollment (and therefore, revenue). It's a business first and foremost, so numbers and growth drive every move, even when the result will clearly be bad for the current students or employees. Many departments are almost fully staffed by inexperienced folks with no investment in the university, creating significant bottlenecks in otherwise simple procedures. There is rarely room for promotion, unless a department head or manager quits, then someone who will work for cheap is randomly elevated. As an educational institution, Lindenwood doesn't have a very good reputation. Their main advertising angle is how convenient it is to go to school there, because there aren't many degree programs worth bragging about and students are generally unhappy.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Saint Charles, MO
pros: Great co-workers, Decent paycheck, and 2 free lunches a week.
cons:
They want to say they care about the students and that it is a small school where they aren't just a number. The Truth is the upper level people that make the decisions  don't care at all about the student or the families they just want their money!! They will flat out lie to the students, conveniently leave out information, and make it so hard to ask a question that them just give up.  And they hide in their offices and make you out to be the liar and the fall person.
They are the same way with employees. They don't care. You can make your goal and the supervisor will take credit and no appreciation will be given to you, you a lucky if you get a 10 cents an hour raise, and they are constantly taking away employee benefits.

review_title: Great place to make a change
job_title: IT Engineer in Saint Charles, MO
pros:
For the most part there is a cooperative attitude between departments. The University is making great changes in accordance with a new strategic plan to prepare for the challenges higher education is facing across the country. I appreciate the lengths that are being undergone to bring more organization and structure to the budgeting.  The CIO and AVP have enabled the relatively large scale changes to infrastructure trusting their engineers for design and implementation. If the president and board did not listen to the management teams well articulated plan the large scale infrastructure improvements could never have happened. I cannot overemphasize the quality of the current CIO.

I enjoyed working at the University and would be happy if I had a professional relationship in the future.
cons: Lindenwood is a tight shop. The teams are small so the workload could overwhelm, however if you are motivated this probably isn't a problem.

job_title: Public Safety Officer in Saint Charles, MO
pros: The only pro I can possibly think of is the free tuition.
cons: The administrative staff are completely unaware of the everyday responsibilities of their employees, and have no idea what a fully staffed department is. I was constantly having to train new employees and have seen over 30 fellow Officers quit. The workload is too much for just one person to handle, yet nothing was done to solve the issues. The training regiment there is pitiful and I had officers scared to work the day shift because of this. On top of that the Associate director basically pushes the free education down your throat in order to corner you into staying for fear of college debt. Also they forget to mention that if you quit in the middle of your classes you are stuck with a bill for the classes. I would not recommend this sketchy position to anybody.

review_title: As an adjunct I'm only part-time, but the pay is better than other adjunct positions, and the paperwork isn't too bad.
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Saint Charles, MO
pros: The pay is good and the course assignments are made about a year ahead of time. The department heads are knowledgeable and helpful as is the office staff. Bonus..., we don't have to sit through mind-numbing meetings.
cons: Some weeks it feels like we are inundated with paperwork..., more so if you teach undergraduate than at the graduate level. It's quite difficult to get on with a full time position once you work for Lindenwood as an adjunct. It's almost as if they don't see the value in their own people.

job_title: Freshman Admissions Counselor in Saint Charles, MO
pros: The LU Enrollment Management Department is a high quality team with coworkers who challenge you to do your best work. The work-life balance is very solid as you are not pressured to take your work home, but offered opportunities for travel at times depending on your position. The people in this office make the atmosphere fun and encouraging.
cons: At times poor communication within leadership down to employees, but not often (which will happen at most places).

job_title: Assistant Director in Saint Charles, MO
pros: Working and helping students toward their goals is the best thing about working at LU.  The historical traditions of the University are also very nice.
cons: Executive Management plays favorites.  One has to kiss a lot of butt to stay on their good side.  Practice what you preach.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Saint Charles, MO
pros: Depending on the office you work in, depends on the office atmosphere. Generally, the upper management is willing to listen and talk to you about your concerns.
cons: Just because upper management listens does not mean they are always willing to fix the problem. Generally, not good communication between departments.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Saint Charles, MO
pros: The university has a lot of room to grow, and it's positioned well in a rapidly developing city.
cons: There's a lot of conflict between the old and new administration. It's easy to get caught up in talk of how things used to be good. People currently view it as a stepping point or somewhere to finish off your career.

review_title: Admissions office is where it's at

review_title: My experience has been fine teaching students.
